I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The value of innovative strategic knowledge solutions and global best practices are 
accepted  as  critical  factors  for  socioeconomic  advancement.  For  Kazakhstan,  this  is 
underscored in the country’s Strategy 2030 and Vision 2050.1 The country partnership strategy 
(CPS),  2012–2016  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  establishes  demand-based 
knowledge  products  and  services  as  important  tools  with  which  ADB  can  add  value  to 
Kazakhstan’s development.2 These strategy documents highlight the need for Kazakhstan to 
effectively apply knowledge solutions and adopt global best practices so as to become a more 
diversified,  competitive,  and  inclusive  economy  and  go  beyond  the  middle-income-country 
stage. 
 
2.  Against this background, and recognizing ADB’s role as  a knowledge management 
leader in Asia and the Pacific and for Kazakhstan to share its own impressive development 
experience with other developing countries, the government and ADB agreed to establish the 
joint Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program (KEEP) in 2013. The KEEP is designed to 
facilitate a range of strategic knowledge options and global best practices that will enable 
Kazakhstan to respond to current and emerging development opportunities and challenges in a 
well-informed and timely manner.  
 
3.  The  KEEP  is  defined  in  a  memorandum  of  understanding  (MOU)  between  the 
government and ADB.3 The MOU provides the framework (outlining the objective and scope, 
areas of focus, implementation arrangements, and monitoring and evaluation measures) and 
commits the parties to share the cost of a range of knowledge and experience-sharing activities 
during 2013–2015 with total financing of $2.5 million. The KEEP MOU is in Supplementary 
Appendix A. 
 
4.  ADB’s  participation  in  the  KEEP  will  be  through  several  technical  assistance  (TA) 
operations.  The  KEEP  will  be  equally  cost-shared  by  ADB  and  the  government.  It  will 
commence in 2013 with an estimated cost of $500,000. Financing of the KEEP will increase to 
$1.0 million per annum during 2014–2015 with ADB providing $500,000 and the government 
providing the other $500,000 annually. The table outlines the cost-sharing arrangements under 
the KEEP MOU.

5.  This proposed policy and advisory TA will finance Phase 1 of the KEEP in 2013. As the 
TA is innovative, and the first of its kind in ADB where a developing member country cost-
shares a knowledge-sharing partnership on a cash basis, lessons drawn from Phase 1 will 
guide the preparation of the subsequent phases. Details of the TA were discussed and agreed 
between ADB and the government in line with the project design and monitoring framework in 
Appendix 1.4    
 
II.  ISSUES 
6.  Since 1991, Kazakhstan has transitioned rapidly from a low-income country into an 
upper-middle-income country and has rated highly in many socioeconomic indicators. Building 
on its impressive socioeconomic performance, the rapid transformation and acceleration into 
being among the top 30 most progressive countries by 2050 entails new opportunities as well as 
challenges. Innovative strategic knowledge options and global best practices are called for to 
help  the  country  (i)  become  a more  inclusive  and  diversified  economy,  (ii)  develop  better 
institutional and policy mechanisms, (iii) integrate and cooperate better with other countries in 
the region, and (iv) enhance the competitiveness and efficiency of the economy. 
 
7.  Despite  impressive  socioeconomic  performance,  Kazakhstan  faces  a  number  of 
development challenges. These include  
(i)  a narrow economic base, mainly concentrated on the extractive industries, calling 
for diversification;  
(ii)  an aging and limited infrastructure network requiring significant improvement;  
(iii)  a vulnerable finance sector needing innovative approaches to reform;  
(iv)  gaps in institutional and policy development performance requiring reforms and 
capacity strengthening to enhance efficiency;  
(v)  an expanding disparity gap demanding growth to be more inclusive;  
(vi)  limited competition in the economy demanding urgent private sector development 
to enhance competitiveness; and  
(vii)  rapid expansion in regional and global integration, calling for better-informed 
responses to maximize gains. 
 
8.  While  capital  investments  are  important  to  address  these  and  related  development 
issues, a combination approach or the effective use of innovative strategic knowledge solutions 
and global best practices is critical for optimal outcomes. The government recognizes the value-
addition for Kazakhstan’s socioeconomic advancement and has integrated knowledge solutions 
into  its  Strategy  2030  and  Vision  2050.  These  two  key  development  directives  highlight 
Kazakhstan’s demand for knowledge solutions and use of global best practices for it to become 
a more diversified, competitive, and inclusive economy. ADB and other development partners 
have been requested by the government to facilitate knowledge and global best-practice sharing 
in a concerted and timely manner. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of this TA will be enhanced policy formulation capacity of the government to 
support  its  medium  and  long-term  development  strategies.  The  expected  outcome  will  be 
strengthened government capacity and awareness of best practices in the selected areas.  
                                                
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 April 2013.

3 
 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  As part of the KEEP, this TA will support subprojects at the macro, sector, and thematic 
level that facilitate or promote knowledge solutions, capacity development, and exchange of 
global  best  practices.  Because  of  the  dynamic  and  unforeseeable  nature  of  government 
demand for knowledge products and advisory services, the subprojects of the TA and the 
implementation  approach  will  be  flexible  in  order  for  the  TA  to  effectively  respond  to  the 
country’s urgent requirements in a timely manner.  
 
11.  The subprojects to be financed will therefore remain tentative to accommodate that 
flexibility―to provide the scope for adjustment and allow for quick response. While some of the 
subprojects  have  been  discussed  between  the  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Budget  Planning 
(MEBP) and ADB during the KEEP preparation, other subprojects will be firmed up during TA 
implementation. A tentative list of the KEEP Phase 1 subprojects is in Supplementary Appendix 
B. 
 
12.  The criteria for selecting a subproject would be that it (i) supports priority government 
policy reforms and is consistent with the CPS; (ii) is related to implementation of the government 
development strategy; (iii) is considered as an emerging, urgent, and high-priority area where 
ADB can add value; (iv) shows evidence of strong government ownership; and (v) complements 
or synergizes the knowledge support of ADB and other development partners. 
 
13.  The main outputs of the TA will be under the categories of policy advisory and capacity 
development  and  include  (i)  submission  of  analytical  reports  to  the  government,  and  (ii) 
completion of a capacity development program.  
 
14.  Effective  coordination  of  the  executing  agency  with  stakeholders  is  important  for 
successful implementation of the TA. It is assumed that there will be (i) consistent government 
demand for ADB’s knowledge products and services, (ii) effective coordination by the MEBP in 
leading the subproject selection and review process, (iii) strong collaboration and support from 
all relevant stakeholders, and (iv) reliable and accurate data and information are made available. 
The potential risks are that (i) lack of coordination between development partners may lead to 
duplication  of  activities,  and  (ii)  frequent  changes  in  government  priorities  may  result  in 
ineffective use of policy recommendations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which the entire amount will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). After ADB 
approval of the TA, the government will reimburse ADB 50% of the TA cost by depositing 
$250,000 into the TASF account. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Budget  Planning,  through  the  Investment  Policy 
Department, will be the executing agency and will be responsible for supervising and monitoring 
TA  activities.  Implementing  agencies  will  be  those  ministries  or  agencies  responsible  for 
initiating the specific subprojects. 
 
17.  The KEEP Coordinating Committee (KCC), comprising representatives from the MEBP 
and ADB, will be set up to oversee implementation and provide guidance and direction to 
stakeholders. The KCC will have periodic meetings to update and adjust the list of subprojects

4   
 
and core outputs. The two parties will record agreements reached during the meetings and 
attach an updated subproject list with detailed project outline and specific terms of reference for 
additional  subprojects.  The  vice-minister  of  the  MEBP  and  the  country  director  of  ADB’s 
Kazakhstan Resident Mission will review and endorse the subprojects and proposed financing 
plan.  
 
18.  The KCC Secretariat will support the KCC’s work in ensuring the smooth functioning of 
the  committee  and  supervise  and  coordinate day-to-day  TA  activities,  including monitoring 
progress,  resolving  issues,  arranging  meetings,  and  liaising  with  concerned  agencies.  An 
overview of the KCC and its secretariat is in Supplementary Appendix C.  
 
19.  Monitoring  of  the  TA  (Phase  1)  will  be  results  oriented.  A  main  measurement  for 
subproject outcome is to see if recommendations emanating from the TA are used by the 
government. Monitoring will be done by the KCC through its secretariat. The KCC Secretariat 
will coordinate closely with all agencies carrying out the subprojects and ensure issues arising 
are addressed at an early stage. Under the overall direction and guidance of the KCC, the KCC 
Secretariat shall prepare quarterly progress reports and a TA completion report. The final 
evaluation  of  the  TA  will  be  based  on  performance  indicators  outlined  in  the  design  and 
monitoring framework (Appendix 1).  
 
20.  Good  practices  and  lessons  will  be  disseminated  by  the  KCC  through  reports  and 
workshops and will also be posted on the ADB and government websites. The KCC will ensure 
that  these  good  practices  and  lessons  are  adequately  reflected  in  subsequent  KEEP 
subprojects, and related government and ADB operations.  
 
21.  Implementation of the TA will be over a 12-month period, commencing in July 2013 and 
closing in July 2014. As subprojects are identified during implementation, flexibility  will be 
maintained in the engagement of consulting services. Where there is need for single source 
selection,  this  will  be  coordinated  with  Operations  Services  and  Financial  Management 
Department (OSFMD). Engagement of all consultants under the KEEP will be in line with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements will 
be in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). 
 
22.  For the identified subprojects (Supplementary Appendix B), about 6 person-months of 
international consultancy services and 12 person-months of national consultancy services are 
envisaged. Additional consultants will be recruited to carry out well-defined tasks during TA 
implementation. Given the nature of the activities to be undertaken, specific terms of reference 
for the consultants will be prepared as soon as the subprojects are finalized. The KCC will 
discuss  and  finalize  the  required  expertise  and  detailed  terms  of  reference  of  specific 
assignments, including duration and expected results. The generic outline on the scope of work 
to be carried out by the consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a reimbursable 
basis, as discussed in para. 15, to the Government of Kazakhstan for the Joint Government of 
Kazakhstan and the Asian Development Bank Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, 
Phase 1, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8    Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance for the Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program (KEEP), 
Phase 1 will use an estimated 12 person-months of national consulting services and 6 person-
months of international consulting services to support analytical research, workshops, and other 
agreed subprojects. The international consultants will serve as the team leaders of the specific 
subprojects,  which  will  be  supported  by  one  or  more  national  consultants  to  facilitate  the 
effective and timely subproject delivery.  
2.  The  consultants  and  resource  persons  shall  serve  to  introduce  international  best 
practices; provide in-depth local knowledge; and advise on policy options, challenges, and the 
implications of various courses of action. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage 
experts in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). The experts will be individual consultants or recruited from consulting firms, 
research institutes, think tanks, academic institutions, or government research bodies. 
 
3.  Given the flexible nature of Phase 1 of the KEEP, specific terms of reference (TOR) for 
the required expert will be developed based on the requirements of each subproject after 
approval  of  the  subproject  by  the  KEEP  Coordinating  Committee  (KCC),  comprising 
representatives  from  the  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Budget  Planning  (MEBP)  and  ADB.  In 
general, the outline TOR for consultants and resource persons engaged for the subprojects will 
include the following.  
 
A.  Consultants for Analytical Research and Policy Advisory Services 
 
4.  In close coordination with the ADB task managers, government focal points, the KEEP 
coordinator, and relevant stakeholders, the consultants will perform the following tasks within 
the given tentative time schedules: 
(i)  undertake research and analyses, as required in the specific TOR prepared by 
implementing agencies and endorsed by the MEBP and ADB; 
(ii)  provide practical recommendations on the government’s immediate policy options 
to address development constraints, taking into consideration information from the 
experience-sharing and best-practice dissemination activities; 
(iii)  generate study reports and policy briefs (e.g., policy research studies, policy notes, 
project  implementation  assessments,  good  practice  studies,  and  sector  and 
thematic reports); 
(iv)  prepare background information and documents for the meetings between ADB 
and the MEBP, and provide assistance, as requested, to implementing agencies 
and subproject task coordinators; and 
(v)  supervise  the  administrative  functions  of  research  support  personnel,  such  as 
compiling information and collecting data for the research studies, and providing 
other support to the MEBP and ADB staff. 
 
B.  Consultants for Capacity Development Services 
 
5.  In  collaboration  with  the  KEEP  coordinator  and  in  consultation  with  the  ADB  and 
government  focal  points,  the  consultants  will  perform  the  following  tasks  within  the  given 
tentative time schedules:

APPENDIXES Appendix 3  9 
 
(i)  propose to the MEBP and the implementing agencies a capacity development 
framework that ensures that programs include active learning, case studies and 
follow-up tasks, and useful tools;   
(ii)  design  and  conduct  a  training-of-trainers  program  to  support  capacity 
development for government officials, as well as the beneficiaries as required;  
(iii)  propose  and  organize  conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  focus  group 
discussions, training, and other knowledge-sharing meetings; and 
(iv)  lead the (a) dissemination of the findings of studies or best-practice cases, (b) 
establishment of effective policy dialogue among stakeholders, (c) consultation 
on the policy directions and development strategy to support implementation of 
the 5-year plan, and (d) training and development of the capacity of government 
agencies  that  may  assume  executing  agency  responsibilities  for  future  ADB 
technical assistance projects. 
 
C.  Resource Persons for Policy Advisory or Capacity Development Services 
 
6.  In  close  cooperation  with  the  KEEP  coordinator  and  in  consultation  with  ADB  and 
government focal points, the resource persons will perform the following specific tasks within the 
given tentative time schedules: 
(i)  facilitate workshops (including conferences or training seminars),  
(ii)  act as discussants or panelists on related policy issues,  
(iii)  present research results,  
(iv)  review reports and/or comment on others' research, and 
(v)  prepare studies on specific fields (e.g., public—private partnership)  
 
D.  General Qualifications 
 
7.  The consultants are required to have a post-graduate degree in the relevant field related 
to the subprojects. Relevant work experience in Kazakhstan and/or Central Asia on related 
issues  would  be  an  advantage.  Proven  technical  experience  in  the  key  aspects  of  the 
subprojects and fluency in written and oral English are required. 
 
E.   Time Frame 
 
8.  It is envisaged that consultants or experts will be engaged for an average of 2 person-
months for analytical research and policy advisory work and about 14 person-days for capacity 
development services.
